text: Happy Monday! Excited to say that my final dissertation paper has been accepted at @@116631's Ed Finance and Policy journal and a version can be found online. This paper has meant a lot to me and I am so stoked that it found a home in one of my favorite outlets. doi.org/10.1162/edfp...

Have any of y'all ever thought about using voter registration data for research that was available but only for "political purposes"? Trying to figure out what that phrase captures exactly/what the law in TN is trying to prevent from happening with this information...

Calculated it myself! Using data from the CCD and some data I have from old OCR surveys, h/t Sarah Reber. Sort of comically, whenever I need a refresher on how to calculate this, I actually go to the same page: www.dartmouth.edu/~segregation...
23/23 And sometimes, we don't even realize when A past IS also part of OUR past.

22/ I told Sarah the other day that the number of years from today to her day of birth is greater than the number of years from her day of birth to the day Brown v. Board was decided. As Faulkner wrote "The past is never dead. It's not even past".

21/ I write this all partially because it is my own story and despite that fact, I am still shocked at how pervasive school segregation is in the present day. It is everywhere, from the urban core, to urban/suburban divides, to small towns far(ish) from a city like my own hometown of Freehold.
20/ Within district school segregation by race/ethnicity has decreased across the two Freehold districts. But across district segregation has actually increased!

19/ In the present day, that same index is 64% (sn: the dissimilarity index is not affected by overall representation of any particular subgroup, which is important given demographic shifts in Freehold). In other words, since the era of school desegregation...

18/ In 1969, the Freehold Borough+Township dissimilarity index was .57. 57% of Black/Hispanic students would have needed to switch schools for all schools in the combined district to have the same proportion of Black/Hispanic students.

17/ But what about calculating these indices for both districts together? Put differently, what if we tried to have all schools across Freehold Township and Borough combined (remember that Borough is surrounded by the Township) have the same racial/ethnic composition for students?
16/ In the present day, this has dropped for both. The dissimilarity indices are now .12 and .08. Within school segregation has decreased in the two Freehold school districts.

In 1969, the dissimilarity indices for Freehold Township/Borough schools? .15 and .26, respectively. This meant that, for Freehold Township, 15% of Black/Hispanic students would have needed to switch schools for each school to have the same racial/ethnic representation as the district as a whole.
14/ As an education scholar, it's always fun to now think about my schools I attended growing up and the data that exists on them. I pulled up the Freehold Borough/Township school information.
13/ I wonder - how many small towns are like this across the U.S.? Potentially far away from urban cores but where school segregation exists because of district boundaries drawn for whatever reason?

12/ Now when I see this map, I immediately think about school segregation. What's striking to me is that Freehold Borough and Freehold Township are typically not what we (or at least I) think of when I think about between district segregation. I think urban-suburban divides. Not a sleepy town NJ.

11/ What does this have to do with Freehold? Back to the map. While attending public K12 schools I never thought much about the dividing district lines and what it meant for my class peers. But anecdotally, I do remember hearing about differences in which students attended which schools in the area.

10/ Conversely, we observe some district fragmentation occurring, where districts may separate from larger ones. Another iconic example is Shelby County. In 2013, the TN legislature approved a bill that allowed majority White Memphis suburban districts to splinter off.
9/ But in the present day, it is difficult to address segregation across district boundaries. For one, the Milliken v. Bradley decision limits the options for doing so.

8/ There were some efforts to desegregate schools by consolidating coterminous districts. Examples like Charlotte Mecklenburg, Raleigh Wake, Louisville Jefferson come to mind. I recently wrote a paper on consolidations in North Carolina that led to increased school integration by race.

7/ There are some iconic examples of this across the country. Indeed, much of the positive integrative effects of school desegregation following Brown v. Board were undone by White flight from desegregating school districts. Sometimes this resulted in urban-suburban related racial isolation.

6/ What we know now is that much of the present day racial isolation we observe across schools is due to the segregation of youth by race/ethnicity caused by enrollment patterns into different schools separated by district boundaries in the same metro area, or between district segregation.

5/ The first thing we think about when we think about school segregation is often within district segregation, or when students from different racial/ethnic backgrounds attend different schools in the same district. A series of SCOTUS decisions over the years helped to mitigate this segregation.

4/ There are actually two "Freeholds". There's the incorporated township and the incorporated borough. Here's the bigger picture of the geography. The red dots outline the area served by Freehold Township School District. The boundary contains a section that is served by Freehold Borough Schools.

3/ Here you can see my childhood home (yellow star). About a 10 minute walk away was Freehold Borough HS, which Springsteen attended. Despite its proximity, I was not zoned to attend it. Those red dots explain why.

2/ I grew up in a suburban NJ town called Freehold, 1.25 hours out of NYC & Philly. It's not v. notable, with a few exceptions. It's the home of Bruce Springsteen, who references it in a few songs. J.R. Smith was born there. But when I mention it, people seem to most recognize the mall.
1/ A short reflection on the schools in the town where I grew up, and thinking about school segregation.

everyone wants to talk about bots on Mechanical Turk affecting results but have they considered the selection bias induced by social scientists who are more likely to respond to surveys/interviews because of their own experiences with poor response rates???

Y'all should be keeping an eye out for the incredible work of Kathryn McGraw, Kenton Shimozaki, Maria Maria Castillo, De'Ja Wood, and Andy Zhang these next few years. Some of them will be presenting at APPAM/UCEA this fall.

Doc students in our department start on their own research from day 1. The expectation is that these projects end up being presented at conferences and submitted to journals. I can't wait to see where these great papers land!

A joy from this week: the second year PhD students in our department presented their research to the rest of the faculty/students that they worked on for the first class I taught at Vandy (research practicum). It was incredible to see how much they've accomplished.

every once in a while (i.e., when working on a history project) I am reminded about how the 1890 census data was destroyed in a fire (technically, water damage from putting out the fire) - and this fact never fails to shock me (so much data destruction!)

Just joined Bluesky today, so thought I’d introduce myself while waiting for my flight home to DC to take off.

I lead the Urban Institute’s education policy work. My team produces original evidence aimed at informing policymakers of all kinds on a range of topics from prek through postsecondary.
